Especially considering the month, this is the best and most important time to watch what I consider one of cinema's classic masterpieces. <br /> <br />Happy Halloween.
B00006RJHG|4.0|Bob Clark's 1974 chiller classic, which went on to inspire many elements of \\"Halloween\\" and \\"When a Stranger Calls\\", is definitely one of the better, if not best, horror films out there. Period. Not high on blood, but very high on suspense, dread, atmosphere, and out-of-the-dark surprises. A sorority house (to include the lovely Olivia Hussey, the vulgar alcoholic Margot Kidder, and SCTV vet Andrea Martin) falls victim to vicious, violent, and altogether menacing phone calls during the Christmas holidays. Soon, students on campus begin turning up missing. Though some events do go unexplained (which could be positive, considering the mystery involved) and the film tends to go borderline predictable in some sorts, this is undeniably one of the creepiest horror films, with the most tense, moody photography ever captured on film. Keir Dullea and Margot Kidder turn in quite effective performances. Highly recommended.

B000089RV6|5.0|It's hard to imagine that an album released 26 years ago, in August 1980, would still be selling hot to this very day.  Many of the albums that first came out back then are either out of print or selling at a much slower rate now than they were in late 1980.  Not this one.  Australian band AC/DC's first production with Brian Johnson as the lead singer is still \\"flying off the shelves\\", if you would call it that.  To this day, the album with the pitch-black cover and a title to match it have sold over 21 million copies in the USA alone, and about 40 million copies worldwide.  In the USA, this number of copies would land \\"Back In Black\\" among the top 5 best-selling albums of all time, including all of the various editions and formats that have come out since 1980. <br /> <br />This latest version of Back In Black is a new, improved version over the other editions, primarily regarding the package, and also the sound.  The deluxe digipak includes pictures and information of the band, some of which were not seen before within the album jacket.  Also, the sound quality has been enhanced, with more audible details and wider range of notes and the intensity of the beats.  This is likely the result of new digital technology, which was not quite as developed in the early 1980s when the album was initially produced.  Those listeners who have older editions in their collection along with this one can listen to them in succession and compare them.  Then they can hear the difference for themselves. <br /> <br />Within this package is a collection of ten great songs, some of which were released as singles in the USA, and many of which were heard on the radio.  Each of these tracks shares the features of Brian's screaming vocals and the trademark guitar solo act, which is found about midway through each song.  The album begins with the mid-tempo \\"Hell's Bells\\", which starts with a bell ringing, and then an instrumental intro joins the bell, and then Brian starts singing.  If you count the bell, you will notice that it rings a total of 13 times.  \\"Shoot To Thrill\\" follows, a fast-paced number which would make a good dance song for parties or night clubs.  Next comes \\"What Do You Do For Money Honey\\", a moderately fast track in which Brian performs the verses, then screams the chorus with a higher-pitched voice.  Here the guitar solo is found both in the middle and at the end.  Another moderately fast-paced selection, \\"Givin The Dog A Bone\\" comes afterward, where Brian first sings the verses; next he sings the title line and then the group echoes the title line in the chorus.  This would also make a good dance song in parties or night clubs.  Somewhat softer in volume and energy is \\"Let Me Put My Love Into You\\", in which the rest of the group joins Brian in singing a relatively melodic chorus, with good harmony.  This piece slows down at the ending part, which concludes the first half of the album. <br /> <br />The second half of the album (side two of the original LP or cassette, or starting with the 6th track of the CD) begins with the title track \\"Back In Black\\", a mid-paced song with a prominent rhythm.  Perhaps this song has significance for the group, in which they make a come-back with the new singer after the death of their first singer, Bon Scott.  It was a hit in the USA.  Another popular hit is \\"You Shook Me All Night Long\\", a creative and well-written love song, in which Brian sings the verses and everybody joins in for the melodic chorus.  This piece has a good strong beat throughout, after the distinctive guitar intro.  \\"Have A Drink On Me\\" is the B-side of the previous track (on the 45 vinyl single), which also has a powerful beat and could be a good party song.  \\"Shake A Leg\\" is a fantastic dance song, which begins in a stop/start fashion but then picks up the pace.  A good guitar accompaniment to the vocals evolves into a great guitar solo in the middle with fast picking and phenomenal fretwork.  The album ends with \\"Rock And Roll Ain't Noise Pollution\\", which starts out with a slow pounding beat and a lecture.  This relatively slow-paced song makes a statement in response to criticism of rock and roll, and portrays a great finale to this musical production. <br /> <br />This album comes after the untimely death of Bon Scott, the previous lead singer for this renowned group.  Many bands might have decided to end their production of albums and songs after losing a member, especially the lead singer, but AC/DC did not give up after this tragedy.  Instead, they found a singer who could fill the role once held by Bon Scott (though he could never actually replace the original singer himself: there will never be another Bon Scott).  With his own unique voice and manner of presentation, Brian Johnson has the high energy and driven vocal style that proved suitable for an AC/DC lead singer.  This album, \\"Back In Black\\", demonstrates that with its phenomenal sales volume and popularity.  Music which is still enjoyed by long-time fans and sought out by newer listeners (many of whom were probably not even born yet when the album was originally produced) many years after its original appearance would earn the label \\"classic\\".  \\"Back In Black\\" certainly deserves this honorable title.

The characters are developed, the story is moving, and the film is a good one. Kudos to Liev Schreiber for putting it together.

0743289412|5.0|Many may not realize this, although some surely do, that the writings of Stephen King can be grouped into at least two types - classic King and commercial King.    See, the classic King is the real King to me.  He's the one that wrote The Stand, and The Dark Tower series.  He also wrote Misery, Dolores Claiborne, and Lisey's Story.  That's the King I love most - the one who takes us behind the basic scary and goes to the really scary, the scary inside us all.    The commercial King writes what sells.  He writes to make the publishers and the casual fans happy.  He writes what buys the groceries, don't ya know.  He wrote Carrie, and Salem's Lot.  He wrote The Tommyknockers and The Cell.  I've read both Kings, and I do love them both, most of the time.  But once you've had the best parts of King, the classic King, it's so very, very hard to settle for the commercial one.  You do, when that's all that is left at the end of the day.  You always have your dreams though, and they snuggle up tight when the shadows grow long, never letting you forget for one moment what's waiting there, just in the distance.    Sometimes both Kings collide, as they did in The Shining, It, and Needful Things.  Sometimes Randall comes through, and sometimes he stays on the other side of that purple curtain, just like King.    The saying that you can please some of the people some of the time, but not all of the people all of the time is oh so very true with King's published works (and wouldn't we all just love to know about those waiting in the wings, those not published - are they real or are they bools?  We may never know for sure.).  The fans, the critics, the literary scholars, oh to be able to please them all, just once.    As for the fans, well, the casual fans just want to be scared of the things that go bump in the night.  They gobble up everything commercial King writes and demand more, more, more.  They are never satiated, but they are the ones who buy the most of those groceries.They see every movie and they watch every interview.  But see, truth is they are afraid of so much more than what goes bump in the night.  They're afraid to look, and really see, what the real King has prepared as the ultimate feast from the pool.  That's where the devoted fans come in, for they are always there hovering beneath the purple shadows and sending their silent wishes into that long, dark night.  \\"Write the next one\\" they whispered, ever so gently, in his ear as he lay recovering from the horrible, freakish accident that came so very close to ending it all.  Okay, maybe some of them didn't whisper gently, but loudly screamed and begged for the rest.  At any rate, thankfully he complied and we were all rewarded with the ending we thought we were so desperate for (an absolute perfect ending, might I add).  But now we know he's still there, dancing with us in the shadows.  Sure, The Cell came first and it sold - they always do now.  But the more devoted of us, the ones unafraid to look at where the real horrors lie, down deep inside the human soul, and even deeper than that in some, we have been rewarded with a mere morsel of what's yet to come.  Randall's still out there somewhere, waiting.  And the purple curtains still flutter in the breezes.  And let us never forget the moon, for it watches over us all, night after night, in this world and the others.  Yes, there is so very much more to come, and while I can hardly contain my excitement on learning the rest, the other me wonders if I'll be able to endure what truly lies at the bottom of that fascinating and brilliant pool.

Anyway, for some reason, after her death, these guys are on their own - trying to perform magic tricks in London and viciously competing with each other. Bale suddenly acquires a sidekick who wears a hat, glasses, and big mustache, and NEVER says a word (until the very end). However, both Bale and Jackman lose their English accents periodically, which is weird. The whole thing is kind of weird, lots of back and forthing, reading of a journal, etc. Jackman is mad at Bale for causing his wife's death, and Bale really gets bent out of shape about that, and won't take any responsibility.  Somehow Bale gets convicted of Jackman's murder, when there's no way he could have murdered him. Makes no sense. Then the ending - I won't reveal it, but it's moronic, simplistic, and unrealistic.<br /><br />Anybody who likes this movie is easy to please.

B000063JZQ|5.0|This is a first-class FILM based on a Shakespeare play. As always, there's heavy pruning of the lines, but what we're left with is well served by the actors, the authentic medieval setting, and the medium of film itself. This MACBETH is gorgeously staged and performed. Is it violent? Sure -- but so are a lot of other films these days. Why should this be different just because it's Shakespeare? <br /> <br />Let's face it: Macbeth is a dark, bloody and -- at its heart -- nihilistic story. Can we really believe that Scotland will live happily ever after just because the usurper is dead? Shakespeare raises that question at the end, very subtly, and Polanski picks up on it. What I particularly liked here was the emphasis on how quickly ambition can poison the mortal mind, and how one's fate can turn in an instant. There's a thin line between good and evil, between the real and the unreal.  <br /> <br />My Shakespeare professor back in college ridiculed certain details of the film, such as the mysterious dagger witnessed by Macbeth actually appearing on the screen for the audience to see. The idea, as he believed it, is that the dagger is a merely a product of Macbeth's fevered imagination, therefore WE shouldn't be able to see it. But I like how Polanski makes one wonder what the dagger really is. Is it a hallucination? Or the product of some darker force? Polanski's whole take on the story balances on a question -- what is the true nature of evil? <br /> <br />Finally, I want to address all those affronted viewers who have been shaken to their core by what seems to be the most horrific sight of all: the images of naked older women. Please. Get a grip. Those are just bodies. Maybe if Hugh Hefner had really been in charge we'd have had nubile Playboy bunnies standing in as the witches but, alas, he was just the money man, not the director. <br /> <br />Polanski's witches were actually another authentic detail -- even back in those days, the idea of old women going \\"skyclad\\" was a sure sign of evil. Nine hundred years later, people's perceptions haven't changed a bit.

Included with the disc is a 14-page booklet containing song titles/credits/times (no lyrics), band pictures, and thank you's. This is album #2. Recorded at Studio At The Palms (Las Vegas). Label - Island Records.<br /><br />COMMENTS: I wanted to love \\"Sam's Town\\" (named after a 9-story Vegas hotel and casino built in 1979). The Killers' 1st album, \\"Hot Fuss\\" (2004), was such an incredible album... I ran out and bought \\"Sam's Town\\" based on the strength of their debut. \\"Hot Fuss\\" had hit after catchy hit and garnered the band tons of accolades - most notably an American Music Award, a Billboard Music Award and a Grammy nomination. While \\"Sam's Town\\" has grown on me, it still lacks that, um...  punch. I would be surprised if this album won any of the above mentioned awards. There's no brilliant songs like \\"Mr. Brightside\\", \\"Somebody Told Me\\" or \\"Smile Like You Mean It\\" here. No need to compare their 1st and 2nd albums... they're vastly different. Having waited to fully digest this disc, I've come away with the feeling that this is more like a swashbuckling theatrical soundtrack than a rock/alternative album... something Freddy Mercury (R.I.P.) would have really appreciated. It's up, it's down, happy, sad, rock, pop and downright weird (just like some of the classic Queen albums). \\"Sam's Town\\" has several good tracks on it... \\"When You Were Young\\" (hit #18 on the pop charts, but fell quickly after 2 weeks), \\"Bones\\" (their next hit), and \\"Read My Mind\\". There's also some nice piano and acoustic moments on the \\"enterlude\\" and \\"exitlude\\". The rest is downright average, with some songs being utterly forgettable. I've read reviews here on Amazon as well as some of the well-known music mags and \\"Sam's Town\\" is a mixed bag at best (and I agree)... Rolling Stone Magazine (2 stars out of 5), All Music Guide (3 stars out of 5), Blender (4 out of 5), and Spin (3 out of 5). Billboard shows the unit sales dropping from week 1 (315,000 units) to week 2 (102,000 units) to week 3 (62,000 units)... a steady decline can't be a good thing. By the way, is that Ruth Buzzi's kid on the cover? In this case it is to find out who has murdered the man that just may be the last honest man in town.  In this company town, murders seem to be a dime a dozen, some just to mislead, others, just because.  The dialogue is sharp and brief, yet clear as a diamond!! The women can be just as hard hearted as the men, with motives that reach only as far as their wallets.<br /><br />This is another classic detective novel!!!

Through conversation, example and encouragement it is believed that \\"Lady Visitors\\" will transform lives the unfortunate women's lives.<br />Selina Dawes is a prisoner. She is without doubt a gifted writer.

0300108834|5.0|Typically history is told in a very dry, intellectual fashion, trying so hard not to offend anyone by being as impartial as possible. Also other books often cover such a little bit of history that unless you know was going on in the world before it, the book seems abstract and consequently, is hard to follow.  <br />This book sticks so many things together in an increadbly easy to understand format that at last the gaps between all the other history books you read are filled.  <br />And it is told AS A STORY, rather than a series of dry and uninspired facts and lists which makes it fun and intriguing to read.  <br />I daresay this book will be critised for being too brisk, or not quite as impartial as is standard these days. I can also imagine this book will generate controversy as \\"The Da Vinci code\\" did, due to its concise, sometimes oversimplifed nature.  <br />But of course that's missing the point of this book. <br />This book, as a starting point for learning ANY history of the world is an absolute must as far as I'm concerned. Gombrich is a novelist of history and this- his first work is one of the most essential reads I could recommend to anyone.

B000H0MKGK|5.0|When I first heard that John Mayer was revamping his style, I didn't understand why. Mayer now seems totally embarrassed by much of his earlier material, like \\"Daughters\\" (which I still think is a terrific song.) While I understand and appreciate artistic growth, I think it's silly for John to be embarrassed by his earlier material. I'm also not too fond of the darker image (Rolling Stone interview) he seems to be heading toward; however, that's not what this review is about.    From the very first listen, Continuum bowled me over. Gone are the candy lyrics and pop sounds. This record is in a slow, bluesy style with excellent electric guitar all the way through. The greatest thing about this cd is how it flows. Very smooth and each songs transitions well into the next.     My favorite track is probably \\"Stop this Train.\\" I love the lyrics of this song and the simple acoustic accompaniment. If I had to pick a least favorite song, it would have to be the Hendrix' cover, \\"Bold as Love.\\" I don't hate this song by any means, but I like it less than the rest of the cd. This is more a positive reflection on the quality of the cd than a negative reflection on \\"Bold as Love.\\"    All said, I think this cd is terrific. John Mayer has a huge amount of potential and this cd is the first of many good things to come, I'm sure. I just hope that John isn't so hell-bent on escaping his goody two-shoes pop image, that he foolishly goes in the opposite direction and someday becomes a casualty of the rock and roll lifestyle.    *** It is now September of 2007. One thing has changed since I did this review, and that is my appreciation for the Hendrix cover, \\"Bold as Love.\\" It took a while to grow on me, but now I can really appreciate it as being a valuable part of the cd. For my ears, Continuum is still the best pop cd to come out over the last few years, and I'm still thoroughly enjoying it. ***

B000EULJLU|4.0|I've had the album since the night of the internet leak before the offical sale date.  I bought the CD the morning it came out for a few reasons...the number one reason being to make sure the leaked version was real.  Well, it was.  So I've waited all this time to really review it, hoping to avoid a premature judgement of the album.   <br /> <br />My opinion is the same as many of the other reviewers in that this album just isn't as good as you'd expect it to be.  In the end, the majority of these songs will just be filler tracks for the end-of-career box set of the band's music.  10,000 Days is basicly a Mix Tape. <br /> <br />Vicarious sounds like some other band trying to imitate Tool.  That song is just a big disappointment, and I hate it.  The lyrics actually sound simplisticly pretentious.  I never thought I'd ever say that about Maynard's lyrics, but its the truth.  Its like he's trying to make some big interesting point or observation, but lacks the poetic ability to express it without sounding like a 6 yr old who just discovered a dictionary and thesaurus.  I can't believe this song is a Tool song.  I hate it, I hate it, I hate it.  Funny how it is STILL better than most other modern 'rock.' <br /> <br />Jambi is good, but like all of the songs it stands by itself.  It doesn't really cohere with the rest of the songs to form some larger piece of work, like Aenima and especially Lateralus.  Those two albums had their own sound, and any song from those albums heard by itself still sounded like \\"oh, this is from Aenima\\" or \\"this is from Lateralus.\\"   <br />10,000 Days just sounds like several individual songs, instead of one album comprised of smaller bits.  Most Tool fans seem to like this song because its \\"harder.\\"  I personally don't listen to hardly any \\"metal\\" anymore, and Tool being \\"hard\\" or not doesn't matter to me. If it is a good song, then its a good song.  Jambi is a good song. <br /> <br />The pair of \\"Wings\\" songs are good, and form their own little requiem masterpiece.  But again, the rest of the album lacks any sort of similarity with them. <br /> <br />The Pot is a good song on its own.  But it sounds like a b-side, and it is surpisingly catchy for Tool.  The message is interesting though.   <br /> <br />Lost Keys/Rosetta Stoned cinematic opening then it goes into the whole useless prophet idea. Musically, this song is kinda simple, but that sort of helps to drive the point of the lyrics.   <br /> <br />Intension is very remniscent of Lateralus.  Almost sounds like it should be on that album.  Lots of tabla and etheral sounndscapes. <br /> <br />Right In Two.  My favorite song on the album.  This also sounds like it could have been on Lateralus, except it's lacking the alchemical references in the lyrics.  This follows Intension very nicely.  They sound like they belong on the same album. <br /> <br />With the album lacking an overall coherence among the songs, it comes off sounding like a mish-mash.  Like it wasn't as well thought out as previous albums.  Like they couldn't pick a direction to move in, whereas Aenima and Lateralus, even Undertow, had an established momentum.  The lack of a this ends up sounding like you're listening to songs that were written at different times in the artists' own development.  Here's a song from when he was 23.  Here's one from after he read that one book.  Here's one from his grieving period after his mother died.   <br />10,000 Days comes off as an EP.  A collection of songs that didn't fit in on the other albums.   Don't get me wrong...the songs on 10,000 Days are good (except Vicarious).  These songs are definitely good.  They just don't form one consistent artistic package.   <br /> <br />The best I can say about 10,000 Days is that, except for the Wings songs, the lyrics are all very referential to the current political, media, and cultural climate existing in the U.S. right now.  Maybe this eclectic Mix Tape is what we should expect to come out of this decade?

0007718721|5.0|ANGELA'S ASHES tells the story of the author's childhood from his earliest memories in New York, his return to that America as a nineteen year old and the intervening years in Ireland.  His parents Angela and Malachy McCourt had met at a dance and we forced into marriage due to the imminent arrival of the author.  Neither parent was up to the task of caring for a family, it is implied that their families had been quite happy to see them emigrate to America and were less than thrilled at their return a few years later with children in tow.   <br /> <br />The McCourt children were left from an astonishingly young age to raise each other.  As the story opens four year old Francis and his three year old brother are responsible for their year old twin brothers.  Their father is usually out of work, a victim of the Depression, his Northern accent - unpopular in southern Limerick, his lack of education and his pride.  On the rare occasions that he does manage to get work he inevitably will lose the job by the third week, along with the pay envelope in the nearest pub.  Angela is perpetually pregnant, bringing the children into the world handing them over to the older ones to tend as the family sinks further into poverty. <br /> <br />As McCourt grows up his perception of his life changes, as a young child he sees his parents as all powerful beings struggling to care for the family in a hostile world.  As McCourt grows up he realizes that not all children have only sporadic meals of tea and bread, live in filth or have fathers that drink up money meant for food or rent.  By the time he reaches his teens McCourt has also come to recognize that his mother also is not the long suffering innocent victim that he had seen her as earlier.  The reader is able to see the family decline over the years to increasingly worse housing, fewer meals and yet continue to survive as the children struggle to escape their background. <br /> <br />There are tender and even funny moments in thischildhood memoir as well.  Malachy tries to show his children the glories of the Irish past, both parents attempt to put the best light on their circumstances possible, referring to the flooded lower floor of their apartment as 'Ireland' and the relatively warmer drier upstairs rooms as 'Italy'.  McCourt describes the happier moments of his childhood as well, the wild games in the streets, the exciting highlights of Confirmation or bits of enlightment when he gets a glimpse of life beyond the slums of Limerick. <br /> <br />McCourt's style is a bit unusual, many of his sentences go on to seeming infinity, making a rather slow reading at time.  The effort pays off though as he turns the bleak grimness that he describes into a sort of poetry.  This is one of those books that celebrates the indominatable human spirit, the power that some have to rise above the worst of circumstances to succeed in life.  <br /> <br />ANGELA'S ASHES is a book that belongs on everyone's book shelf, a book that needs to be taken down and read again and again.
B0009P42S2|5.0|I don't know anime but I know what I like. I liked \\"Steamboy\\", Katsuhiro Otomo's 2004 film, even though the idea of a sort of industrial revolution era sci-fi did seem a little odd at first. <br /> <br />Ray Steam is a boy growing up in 1860s Manchester. His grandfather and father are both engineers, and pioneers in steam based technology. On a trip to Iceland, these relatives discovered a liquid that could be transformed into a high density, high pressure steam, which could fuel machinery with a minimum loss of energy. With this liquid, bolted up inside black metal \\"steam balls\\", almost anything can be achieved. This is science at its most powerful, and has many international eyes turned toward Great Britain. Plot and counter-plot are uncovered, intentions are made known and the Steam Castle (a giant floating fortress, powered by steam) is revealed. Ray's father wants to world to see it, his grandfather wants it torn apart. Scarlett O'Hara, an American heiress to a businessman's fortune, is just there for the ride, and for Ray's company. Ray, however, is very confused. These are very confusing times? What will he do? <br /> <br />It's interesting seeing England (and London in particular) through Japanese eyes. The London of \\"Steamboy\\" is a little on the theoretical side, everything looks well researched and studied, but it does lack a bit of that charm, warmth and pomp that the English landscape, architecture and people have. The accents and the use of British slang in the English dub, for instance, feel a little bit pushed. Still, it is a very atmospheric backdrop, and suits the story well, I thought. The characters are fairly interesting to watch, which keeps the more philosophical dialogue (the nature of science, etc) from seeming over the top. There is action, but it is diluted a bit by the atmosphere, the colours and the slabs of dialogue between shots. I didn't really mind though, left me time to think about what was being explored. <br /> <br />Special features include several making of segments, original production drawings, original theatrical trailer, and some pre-visual bits and pieces. <br /> <br />Worth a look for fans of anime, fans of the Victorian era and maybe lovers of the older style of sci-fi (like Jules Verne, H.G. Wells, etc).
B00005JPAD|5.0|Martin Scorsese's \\"The Departed,\\" a remake of a 2002 Hong Kong film, \\"Infernal Affairs,\\" is profane, violent, darkly humorous, sexy, and incredibly entertaining.  The theme is an intriguing one.  What if two handsome and brilliant young men both graduate from the Massachusetts State Police Academy but take opposite paths?  One becomes a detective but is really a mole for a big-time mobster.  The other pretends to be a gangster, but is really a cop trying to bring down the aforementioned mob boss.<br /><br />Matt Damon plays Colin Sullivan, who has been groomed since childhood by kingpin Frank Costello (Jack Nicholson) to infiltrate the cops and feed him secret information.  Sullivan starts out an altar boy, but under Frank's tutelage, he becomes an accomplished liar who sells out his colleagues for personal gain.  Leonardo DiCaprio plays Billy Costigan.  His father was an honest man who held a menial job at an airport and refused to do anything illegal, but Billy's uncle was connected to the mob.  Costigan is not warmly welcomed into the police department.  In fact, Sergeant Dignam, played with a nasty and sardonic edge by Mark Wahlberg, mocks Costigan's ambition.  Oliver Queen (Martin Sheen), Dignam's boss, informs Costigan that the only way he will ever be a cop is if he agrees to work under deep cover, pretending to be one of Costello's soldiers but, at the same time, informing on him and helping to bring him down.  In a sense, Sullivan is Costigan's doppelganger, a person who resembles him superficially but embodies everything that Costigan despises.  Costello, who has never had a child, is, in a sense, Sullivan's and Costigan's twisted father figure.<br /><br />Costigan and Sullivan eventually find that living a double life is stressful and dangerous; having to lie constantly takes a terrible toll on one's peace of mind.  Complicating matters further, they both fall in love with the same woman, a beautiful police psychiatrist named Madolyn (Vera Farmiga).  Soon, both Costello and the cops suspect that there are \\"rats\\" in their organizations, and Sullivan ends up in charge of the search for Costello's mole (himself).  DiCaprio is terrified that his true identity will be discovered and he is desperate to come in from the cold before he ends up on a slab.<br /><br />Does this film sound a tad too complicated?  That it is, but the plot is not the reason to see this terrific movie.  The performances carry the day, with Nicholson playing Costello as a sadistic, lascivious, manipulative, and evil Svengali.  Seeing Nicholson's superlative performance is alone worth the price of admission.  DiCaprio shines as Costigan, an edgy young man whose desperation to escape his past leads him to explore dark corners of his personality that he would prefer not to acknowledge.  Damon is effective as a man who sells his soul to the devil and lives to regret it.  Scorsese does a wonderful job of integrating his large cast seamlessly. The lively screenplay is peppered with hilarious lines that provide needed comic relief and  the film's editor, Thelma Schoonmaker, helps maintain the film's rapid and exciting pace.  The suspense in \\"The Departed\\" builds relentlessly, just like a Shakespearean tragedy in which an arrogant hero's hubris, greed, and overarching ambition bring him crashing down to earth.o and the cops suspect that there are \\"rats\\" in their organizations, and Sullivan ends up in charge of the search for Costello's mole (himself). The suspense in \\"The Departed\\" builds relentlessly, just like a Shakespearean tragedy in which an arrogant hero's hubris, greed, and overarching ambition bring him crashing down to earth.
B00005JOFQ|5.0|There really is so much to say about this movie, condensing it all into a short review is impossible. To put it as simply as possible, Brokeback Mountain is a work of art that slowly and almost subliminally works its way into your psyche, refusing to hint at or portray its message until the very end, at which point your emotions virtually devastate you.<br /><br />The storyline is pretty well-known now. Jack and Ennis, two 19-year-old ranch hands, are hired in the early 1960's to tend to a flock of sheep atop the grazing grounds of Brokeback Mountain in Montana. Jack, the son of an overly strict and distant father, is quick to make friends and laugh, while Ennis, an orphan raised by his brother and sister, is shy, withdrawn, and almost gun-shy of society. During the course of the summer, Jack gradually draws Ennis out of his shell and the two unexpectedly start a sexual relationship. At the end of summer, each goes their own way and start traditional families, but cannot deny the feelings they have for each other. They then maintain a 20-year romance through camping and fishing trips several times a year.<br /><br />The execution of this movie is near flawless! Cinematography is so beautiful at points, it's almost too much for the eyes to comprehend. The musical score is understated and feels perfectly at home within the film. Direction is near perfect. The film never loses focus of the two actors... from the opening scene to the end, this is a movie about them. Supporting characters are never dismissed, and though the attention is not focused on them, they are nonetheless memorable without ever stealing the scenes from the actors. The only drawback to the film is the makeup. The 2nd part of the film takes place over a span of 20 years, and shows the actors gradually aging from 19 to 39. The makeup isn't quite up to the job to make these young actors appear middle-aged and weathered. In all honesty though, I'm not sure any makeup anywhere can fully pull that off.<br /><br />As for the actors, Jake Gyllenhall and Heath Ledger played their roles beautifully. It quickly becomes apparent that the actors chose these parts not for the money, nor for any fame (it was never meant to be released as a major film), but rather because they believed in the story and wanted to portray their characters as best they could. Jake gives life to Jack in a refreshingly wonderful manner, and Heath disappears, leaving behind the withdrawn, shell-shocked Ennis.<br /><br />The movie progresses at a very slow pace. It's never boring, but throughout one wonders where the film is going and what it's trying to say. That sentiment continues to grow and almost threatens to lose you as an audience member until the last 20 minutes or so. At that point, the plot takes a sudden and surprisingly-devastating turn. It's surprisingly devastating because you simply don't expect to have made such an emotional connection with the characters, but found that you have. As the film reaches it's emotional impact, it becomes achingly apparent that it has woven itself under your skin and is now a part of you... it has its claws in you and is not letting go. As it climaxes, you're left with a rush of emotion that surprises you and that few films have ever been able to garner. It's at that point where you realize the purpose of everything previously in the film. The entire film is a leadup to one simple message, one simple premise. It's that gut-wrenching realization at the end that lingers in your mind long after you've walked away from the screen.<br /><br />The movie is honest. It documents and portrays. It makes no statement for or against homosexuality. It is unapologetic, yet compassionate. It's an all-time classic.. <br /> <br />As for the actors, Jake Gyllenhall and Heath Ledger played their roles beautifully. It quickly becomes apparent that the actors chose these parts not for the money, nor for any fame (it was never meant to be released as a major film), but rather because they believed in the story and wanted to portray their characters as best they could. Jake gives life to Jack in a refreshingly wonderful manner, and Heath disappears, leaving behind the withdrawn, shell-shocked Ennis. <br /> <br />The movie progresses at a very slow pace. It's never boring, but throughout one wonders where the film is going and what it's trying to say. That sentiment continues to grow and almost threatens to lose you as an audience member until the last 20 minutes or so. At that point, the plot takes a sudden and surprisingly-devastating turn. It's surprisingly devastating because you simply don't expect to have made such an emotional connection with the characters, but found that you have. As the film reaches it's emotional impact, it becomes achingly apparent that it has woven itself under your skin and is now a part of you... it has its claws in you and is not letting go. As it climaxes, you're left with a rush of emotion that surprises you and that few films have ever been able to garner. It's at that point where you realize the purpose of everything previously in the film. The entire film is a leadup to one simple message, one simple premise. It's that gut-wrenching realization at the end that lingers in your mind long after you've walked away from the screen. <br /> <br />The movie is honest. It documents and portrays. It makes no statement for or against homosexuality. It is unapologetic, yet compassionate. It's an all-time classic.
B000I2J5UG|5.0|\\"The Black Parade\\" by My Chemical Romance will become a classic.  This concept CD,  a rock opera,  will withstand the test of time.  The story is centered around \\"The Patient\\" a man who is dying tragically young.  Death,  as lead singer Gerard Way likes to believe, comes for us however we want, as our strongest memory.  The Patients strongest memory  is of his father taking him to a parade when he was a boy.  Now death is coming for him in the form of The Black Parade.  Fear and Regret along with Mother War also accompany him on this journey.  The songs on this CD tear at our emotions.  We feel his fear,  his hopelessness,  disenchantment,  and sorrow.  We also feel his hope at the end in the song \\"Famous Last Words\\".  My Chemical Romance proves they have not forgotten hard hitting rock tunes like \\"House of Wolves\\" and \\"Sharpest Lives\\".  They offer us something different in the song \\"Mama\\" which even contains a cameo by Liza Minnelli and bring us to tears with the song \\"Cancer\\".  Gerard Way's voice has never been stonger or better.  He can belt out obscenties one moment then caress us with his voice the next.      <br />This Special Edition Set comes in a velvet hinged box.  Inside are pictures and a wonderful booklet made to look like a Victorian Photo Album.  The booklet begins with a glimpse into the mind of Gerard Way.  He tells of the struggles the band endured making this CD and the personal struggles he endured as well.  The depth of his emotion rings true and clear.  His brother Mikey and drummer Bob Bryar also tell us their stories and share their feelings.  Remaining members Ray Toro and Frank Iero go song for song offering insights into each one.  This booklet complements the CD wonderfully.  This CD and booklet are outstanding works of art not to be missed. <br />

B0006ZE7G2|3.0|For my generation, bottle-fed mind-journeys like \\"Set the Controls for the Heart of the Sun\\" and \\"Echoes,\\" as well as primal, jamming instrumentals such as \\"Any Colour You Like,\\" this is when the Floyd sold out.  Transparent pandering to teenage angst and unspeakably commercial.  \\"We don't need no education\\" -- give me a break.<br /><br />Still haven't seen the film and never will.<br /><br />We were all crushed when this was released.  It seemed nothing at all like \\"our\\" Floyd -- precious little of the weird time signatures and keys, way-too-long-for-radio songs, cosmic themes, etc.  Should have included a subtitle \\"We went for the money, mates.\\"<br /><br />Of course, it's well-produced -- we'd expect nothing less of the band.  And Mother, Hey You and the breathtaking Comfortably Numb do make the album worth a buy -- grudgingly, on principle alone.  Gilmour's work on CN is, of course, jaw-dropping to anyone who's ever picked up a guitar.  It almost -- almost -- saves the double album.<br /><br />But don't expect much more from this crude, self-indulgent, materialistic nightmare from Waters.  Hard to believe he consciously prostituted himself and the band's credibility for such vulgar, base commercial success -- and harder still to believe the band would have let him.<br /><br />Perhaps it was subconscious.  The man has shared his hopes, fears and wonders with us so sublimely over the years, I'll have to give him the benefit of the doubt.<br /><br />But, conscious or not, if you look in the rock dictionary for the word \\"sellout,\\" you'll see this album cover.<br /><br />Just one fan's opinion...

0618680004|5.0|Ever since the January release of Richard Dawkins' antireligious documentary The Root of All Evil?, I have been avidly anticipating the release of his newest book in which he takes on the widespread belief in God. As a biologist at the University of Oxford, his mastery of his field and the philosophy of science, coupled with his gift for writing, renders him one of today's most important intellectuals. Dawkins has become the spokesman for atheism today as its boldest advocate and its greatest defender.  <br /> <br />Dawkins begins The God Delusion by defining the God Hypothesis as the belief that \\"There exists a superhuman, supernatural intelligence who deliberately designed and created the universe and everything in it, including us.\\" In rejecting this proposition, he upholds another: \\"Any creative intelligence, of sufficient complexity to design anything, comes into existence only as the end product of an extended process of gradual evolution.\\" Thus, Dawkins rejects any notion of a \\"prime mover.\\"  <br /> <br />Dawkins also rejects the popular notion that religion stands protected outside of the realm of debate or questioning. There is an important discussion of what biologist Stephen Jay Gould termed NOMA, or \\"non-overlapping magisteria,\\" the belief that science and religion do not conflict because they address different questions. Dawkins vehemently rejects this thesis, arguing that theologians have nothing of value to offer human wisdom, and suggesting that just because religion has nothing else to contribute to our knowledge doesn't qualify it to answer questions such as, Why are we here? And, Dawkins notes, who is to say science can't someday answer that question, too?  <br /> <br />In chapter 3, Dawkins addresses a multitude of arguments in favor of the God Hypotheses with a reply to each, followed by a bold yet convincing chapter titled \\"Why There Almost Certainly is No God.\\" As an expert in the theory of evolution, what follows is much discussion of the fossil record, the process of accumulating complexity, and an application of both to the concept of an intelligent designer. He then quickly moves on to discuss the evolutionary roots of religion in order to explain its adaptive nature in the face of its great costs in terms of money, time and privation.  <br /> <br />Dawkins then goes on to address morality, investigating why it is that humans behave morally, and scrutinizing the claim that religion is the sole source of morality. Dawkins draws from anthropological evidence to support his claim that morality predates religion, and that it is in fact religion that conforms to our innate conceptions of morality rather than vice versa. And even if it were true that humans needed religion to behave morally, Dawkins points out, this fact would be irrelevant to the truth value of religious claims.  <br /> <br />Dawkins then goes on to analyze the Bible and finds it to be morally appalling and packed with absolutely repulsive acts of bloodshed and grief. Many of the Bible's protagonists are racist, sexist, xenophobic war-mongers. The lead protagonist, God himself, is for Dawkins \\"the most unpleasant character in all fiction: jealous... a petty, unjust, unforgiving control-freak... a mysogynistic, homophobic, racist, infanticidal, genocidal, ...megalomaniacal, sadomasochistic, capriciously malevolent bully.\\" Not the omnibenevolent being Christians claim him to be.  <br /> <br />Yet, God enjoys no shortage of supporters across the world, and in the following chapter Dawkins turns his attention to religious fundamentalism. It is his belief that \\"even mild and moderate religion helps to provide the climate of faith in which extremism naturally flourishes.\\" He blames religion itself for violence and terrorism, \\"not religious extremism - as though that were some kind of terrible perversion of real, decent religion.\\" Of tremendous concern to Dawkins is the tendency of the West to treat religion as a license for believers around theworld to behave like barbarians.  <br /> <br />Dawkins is particularly alarmed by the violent nature of the Qur'an, and quoting an Islam scholar, suggests that Muslim terrorists come from the core of their Muslim communities and are motivated by a mainstream interpretation of their religion rather than an eccentric and extremist fringe interpretation. He reminds us of the Muslim riots in early 2006 that followed depictions of Mohammad in a Danish newspaper, and quoting journalist Andrew Mueller, charges that the rioters assumed \\"that the values of Islam trumps anyone else's - which is what any follower of Islam does... If people wish to love a 7th century preacher more than their own families, that's up to them, but nobody else is obliged to take it seriously.\\"  <br /> <br />In chapter 9, Dawkins addresses the topic that is of seemingly greatest importance to him: the religious indoctrination of children. Since as a survival mechanism, children are evolved to believe what parents and authority figures tell them, Dawkins believes it to be a form of child abuse to inculcate children with the \\"virus of religion,\\" to teach them not to think, and to divide them into in-groups and out-groups based on these faiths. Dawkins is also appalled by the popular habit of labeling children \\"Muslim children\\" or \\"Christian children,\\" even though children are certainly too young and uneducated to form opinions on matters of cosmological importance. We'd never refer to children as Tory or Labour children, and we should treat religions the same way.  <br /> <br />The God Delusion concludes with a discussion of how humans may achieve happiness, purpose, inspiration, and consolation in a world without God. Dawkins believes that reason is the best foundation for such human necessities, and that religion doesn't serve that purpose as well as common sense seems to imply. For him, happiness comes through an appreciation of the only life he will ever know, where he is free to investigate ourmysterious and elegant universe and enjoy all of the beauty therein.  <br /> <br />The God Delusion is interesting all the way through, with a few laughs thrown in for good measure. If the book has a single message, it is that there is nothing wrong or outlandish about atheism, and that life can still have purpose when one chooses to free himself from the delusions of religion. It is Dawkin's ambition that this book will convert readers who don't consider themselves particularly religious, or who have always accepted religious doctrines out of a perceived lack of alternatives. The more religious of the country, however, will not read this book past the title.
B0000714B5|5.0|I stumbled across this and am frankly, somewhat amazed at the negativity of some of the reviews here.  I saw this film in its full-screen glory at age 15 or so in an audience with all of four people, and it had an impact like no other movie before or since.  Research the film, and you'll find a rather strange story behind Conrad Rooks and how the film was made.  Rooks has a very interesting interview included on the DVD.  The film largely languished for more than 30 years in a conflict between Rooks and Columbia Pictures before finally finding the light of day again in the late 1990's.  Rooks is to be commended for using an Indian cast, Indian music, securing shooting locations previously inaccessible to the West, and employing the marvelous Sven Nykvist as cinematographer.  A review at Imdb talks about the effect seeing this movie had on an audience in Sweden in 1974, and I echo what they say.  I also love the Hesse book, and think the DVD makes a great compliment to it.

0618680004|4.0|Let's say I really own a Toyota Camry and then I try to convince you that I own it. So, I construct an argument to try to prove to you that I really own a Camry. After, I state my argument, you find a flaw in the argument and therefore, you conclude that I must really not own the Camry.  But, just because I can't  construct a logical argument doesn't mean that I don't own the Camry. All it means is that I am not very good in constructing convincing arguments.  <br /> <br />When Dawkin's considers the arguments for the existence of God, his logic is the same. He finds valid flaws in previous and present arguments for the existence of God. From there,  he then concludes that, since this or that argument is flawed, God doesn't exist. No, it just means that the argument is flawed...that's it, nothing more.   <br /> <br />Dawkin's does an excellent job of explaining natural selection. Natural selection, as a very \\"no gap\\", free from chance, natural phenomenon. He describes it as, almost a mechanical and methodical builder of complexity. The logic? out of the simplicity of natural selection, complexity is born.  <br /> <br />He then asserts that, in speaking of the existence of God, because the universe is so complex,the God who created it, would have to even be more complex than the universe, and that's just statistically impossible. The logic? if complexity exists then, it must of come from something more complex.  <br /> <br />But wait! There is a contradiction...simplicity birth's complexity, but, in order to have complexity,  something has to exist that is more complex. What? fine, if that's true, then all I have to say, to deconstruct that argument, is that God works in the same way as natural selection. God is simple and out of his simplicity came the complex universe.  <br /> <br />Dawkin's also, talks about theories of the origin of life. He discusses that although it may seem statistically impossible, it happened. Well, I could say the same thing about the existence of a complex God. Although it may seem statistically impossible, for the existence of complex being, even more complex than the universe, God exists.  <br /> <br />Another of his arguments is, who created the creator? That's like asking, what existed before the universe, that created the universe? Did it create itself, wait, that's not possible. It comes down to this, either you believe in the eternality of the universe or the eternality of God. What if they both are eternal? Is it a false dichotomy, having to choose between God and science? Can't they coexist? <br /> <br />Dawkin's target's the most extreme cases of people in religion and situations. It is a very exclusive analysis, there are people, of course, who believe in God, who would stand in agreement with Dawkin's charge against an oppressive literal theological viewpoint. <br /> <br />Finally, he talk's about the destructive force of religion and the belief in God. Although people do things in the name of God and religion that are destructive, it doesn't mean that God doesn't exist. It means that people twist and distort the belief in God and the practice religion to accommodate their agenda. People appeal to a higher authority to justify their evil actions. But, again, that doesn't mean that God doesn't exist. All it means is that you have a crazy person speaking in the name of God and committing atrocities against society. That's like saying, there was someone in the city claiming to represent you and was shooting innocent people, so we are here to arrest you!

0060776757|5.0|U2 by U2 is a book to possess. Unlike so many coffee table books, it's actually better for what it says than for what it shows. Furthermore, this is no exercise in self congratulation, as so many of these sorts of books turn out to be, it's something much greater. Amid a lot of terrific photography is a story as told by those from deep within the inside of the thirty-year project in music and social awareness that is U2. Anyone who ever accuses this band of narcissism and egotism should read this self-deprecating exercise in honesty, humility, and passionate gratitude for all the blessings these four men from Dublin acknowledge they've been given. Long before this quartet played arenas filled with adoring fans, they were unknown Irish boys with big dreams and a lot of almost innocent ambitions. Since their early start on homemade instruments in the mid-1970's, U2 has become not only the greatest rock and roll band active today---achievement enough in and of itself---but as headed by its conscience, U2 has been the force behind humanitarianism truly worthy of a Nobel Prize. U2 by U2 will only disappoint those who want the band to be iconic rather than human. For others, this is a testament in words and pictures to four decades of ups and downs, brilliance and endurance, and it is also just a plain and simple darn good read.

And then the jets were all like wooosh!\\" <br />There is a lot of cheese in this movie, and it has a very predictable plot.  But overall it is worth the adrenaline rush.  I have probably watched this thing 20 times by now, and have many of the lines memorized.  Though it helps that many of the lines repeat themselves, such as \\"Pull up!  Pull up!\\"  And of course this is the movie that gave to guys everywhere the now classic line \\"Talk to me, Goose!\\"  That's a go-to in difficult times... <br />Review by Adam Platts, Northridge. <br />
B000J0UD94|5.0|Director Ridley Scott brings Columbus to life in this impressive film which, when released in 1992, coincided with the 500th anniversary of Christopher Columbus's discovery of new lands surrounding two unknown continents. For this reason alone, the film deserves to be treasured by viewers all over the world. The subject of Conquest Of Paradise, of course is Christopher Columbus, played wonderfully by French actor Gerard Depardieu (Green Card, Cyrano De Bergerac). Depardieu brings a lot to the role, and creates a realistic portrayal of Columbus. I can't see how any other actor, could bring more to the role, than Depardieu did. In terms of casting, Depardieu's a perfect fit for this role, he resembles Columbus, has a nice smile and sort of a middle age appearance to him, with his long shaggy hair. The rest of the cast shines, and engages the audience. Armand Assante, Sigourney Weaver and Michael Wincott are among some of the film's cast members, and the performances they give are solid. The film succeeds on four of its noteworthy merits. The first one would be Scott's directing, and his reputation for incorporating vivid & gorgeous images into all his films, the second one would be its historical accuracy, the third one would be its score, composed by Vangelis, who can create gorgeous paintings like Scott can, but only to the music he makes. Finally the fourth one would be the casting of Depardieu, who can add spice to basically any film that he stars in.     When this film was released most critics were too analytical about it, and the film didn't draw in big crowds. Now, how films like this get lost amongst the trees, is really mysterious. I think this film's a classic, and maybe others will once this film gets its deserved exposure. The film is full of defining Columbus scenes, it's like traveling back in time, if you haven't seen this film, please do so.    This is the 1492 Definitive Edition release out of Brazil. It is region 0 (ALL). It is the first widescreenrelease available in the U.S. The quality is very good and it worth to pay a little more because it is widescreen.

From Death's viewpoint, we learn about: <br />  <br /> \\"A girl <br />  Some words <br />  An accordionist <br />  Some fanatical Germans <br />  A Jewish fist fighter <br />  And quite a lot of thievery\\". <br /> <br />Are you intrigued as I was? I was mesmerized with this little girl whose love of words turned her into a book thief.  I fell in love with a story about a girl like myself, who cherished books, who reveled in words, whose entire life was colored by this obsession. <br /> <br />I have found that it is a rare male author who can write well about girls and women but Markus Zusak has an incredible gift for describing Liesel and her world.  In general, he writes beautifully in a way that sang to me.  He weaves color into his descriptions in a way that I have not seen before: <br />  <br /> \\"The last time I saw her was red. <br />              The sky was like soup, boiling and <br />  stirring.  In some places it burned. <br />  There were black crumbs, and  <br />  pepper, streaked across the redness.\\" <br /> <br />The narrator, Death, prepares the reader for the taste of what is to come in this beautiful tale.  For it is the time of Hitler, the time of terrible suffering and death for innocent Jews, the time in which some people risked their lives and everything they had to stand up against the Nazis.  <br /> <br />I don't want to say too much and give away any of this story.  If you love words and the ways in which they can alter our lives irrevocably, please read this beautiful book, one which I will never forget.   <br />

B000FVQYYK|5.0|I've been a fan of UK rock trio Muse ever since I heard and fell in love with `Newborn' off their sophomore CD `Origin of symmetry', which prompted me to dig up their awesome debut `Showbiz'. I always thought they sounded a bit like a more accessible `Ok computer'-era Radiohead.<br /><br />`Black holes & revelations' is their fourth studio CD, and set to be their biggest, having already hit #1 in the UK and earning them rave reviews from even the snootiest of critics.<br /><br />For the most part, they ditch the Radiohead sound (though lead vocalist Mathew Bellamy still has that desperate/aching Thom Yorke delivery) and add a bit more danceability into the mix, and it works very well.<br /><br />Opening cut is the brilliant `Take a bow' (no, definitely not the Madonna hit) with its dizzying swirling synths and gradually soaring layered sound, just like a rocket. Similar is the incredibly catchy Depeche Mode-like `Map of the problematique'.<br /><br />Current single `Starlight' is an upbeat rocker with swirling keyboards, fuzzy guitars and a sunny sound; very catchy. The falsetto sung `Supermassive black hole' is set against a deep bassline, whining guitars and great harmonies on the chorus. Great!!<br /><br />`Soldier's poem' is a soothing ballad with an almost country feel and haunting backing harmonies. `Invincible' builds up from a soothing start to a jubilant climax, while breakneck buzzing guitars announce the rocking `Assassin'.<br /><br />Every song stands out really, `Exo-politics', the flamenco guitar driven `City of delusion' and the similar styled mournful epic `Hoodoo' (with its radical tempo shifts), and closing is the galloping, aptly titled `Knights of Cydonia' with fuzzy guitars, swirling synths, a Queen inspired bridge, and a triumphant sound.<br /><br />This album is a stunning revelation.

B000002G7G|4.0|John Cale left The Velvet Underground after their second album, and his absence shows on their eponymous third album.  He was the avant-garde musician to Lou Reed's avant-garde lyricist.  Cale's departure did not entail a decline in the quality of the Velvet's records, but that was to some extent the result. The tension between the two pushed both of them to their limits, resulting in the most far out popular music ever recorded at the time.  With Cale's departure, Reed chilled out quite a bit.<br /><br />Not that The Velvet Underground and Loaded, their final album, are bad. They simply lack the elements that made The Velvet Underground the band that they originally were. On their third record, the Velvets started to sound like a more staightforward rock band, which is a large part of why some people (including me) love it. After all, it showed that the band that recorded \\"European Son\\" and \\"The Gift\\" could also record conventional songs. It is this contrast that is so appealing. Still, it was the fearlessness of the debut and its follow-up (White Light/White Heat) that were to make VU one of the most important bands of all time.<br /><br />The opener, \\"Candy Says\\", is beautifully sung in an unlikey falsetto by Doug Yule, for whom this song was his first appearance on a VU album. It was also the first of several Lou Reed songs in which a melancholy and/or jaded female (eg, Stephanie, Lisa) \\"says\\" something. Songs like this one showcase his empathy/sympathy for others in an honest and poetic fashion.  And just as the CD opens with a high-pitched voice that isn't Reed's, it closes with \\"After Hours\\", which is sung in a childlike voice by drummer Moe Tucker. There isn't a lot of electric guitar on this record, but when it does appear - on the classic Velvets tracks \\"What Goes On\\" and the \\"Beginning to See the Light\\" - it is restrained and tasteful, not a feedback-laden headless chicken.<br /><br />The only remnants of the 1967 version of the band are on the epic \\"The Murder Mystery\\" and \\"Some Kinda Love\\".  The former it is not as musically noisy as something from the previous two records, but the overlapping vocal layers provide a cacophony that recalls the \\"early\\" days. This a wonderfully adventuresome track - more so even than \\"Sister Ray\\" - and proof that Lou Reed could toy with conventional song structure without John Cale. And it was quite clever to include this song near the very end of the record, by which point some listeners may have been lulled into complacency by the more normal songs. (That is,  if they haven't already been tipped off by the fact that the song is nearly nine minutes long.) The mid-tempo rocker \\"Some Kinda Love\\", meanwhile, recalls the kinky sexual fantasy of \\"Venus In Furs\\".<br /><br />The remainder of the songs are generally pretty strong. \\"Pale Blue Eyes\\" and \\"Jesus\\" are stark folk ballads, although the latter's \\"I'm a drug-addicted rock star, save me!\\" attempt at irony will be a bit transparent to today's listeners.  \\"I'm Set Free\\" is another decent mid-tempo number, but \\"That's the Story of My Life\\" is a bit of a dud, as it relies a bit too much on the approximate rhyme of \\"life\\" and \\"right\\", just as one the best songs on the disc relies on the exact rhyme of \\"light\\" and \\"right\\".<br />But the better songs on The Velvet Underground make it an above average record, even if it is below the extremely high average for the band that recorded it. Besides, the very essence of this band was to challenge listeners' expectations, and on this album they did so almost if not at least as much as they had on their debut and White Light/White Heat.ome Kinda Love\\".  The former it is not as musically noisy as something from the previous two records, but the overlapping vocal layers provide a cacophony that recalls the \\"early\\" days. This a wonderfully adventuresome track - more so even than \\"Sister Ray\\" - and proof that Lou Reed could toy with conventional song structure without John Cale. And it was quite clever to include this song near the very end of the record, by which point some listeners may have been lulled into complacency by the more normal songs. (That is,  if they haven't already been tipped off by the fact that the song is nearly nine minutes long.) The mid-tempo rocker \\"Some Kinda Love\\", meanwhile, recalls the kinky sexual fantasy of \\"Venus In Furs\\".    The remainder of the songs are generally pretty strong. \\"Pale Blue Eyes\\" and \\"Jesus\\" are stark folk ballads, although the latter's \\"I'm a drug-addicted rock star, save me!\\" attempt at irony will be a bit transparent to today's listeners.  \\"I'm Set Free\\" is another decent mid-tempo number, but \\"That's the Story of My Life\\" is a bit of a dud, as it relies a bit too much on the approximate rhyme of \\"life\\" and \\"right\\", just as one the best songs on the disc relies on the exact rhyme of \\"light\\" and \\"right\\".  But the better songs on The Velvet Underground make it an above average record, even if it is below the extremely high average for the band that recorded it. Besides, the very essence of this band was to challenge listeners' expectations, and on this album they did so almost if not at least as much as they had on their debut and White Light/White Heat.

B000002JR8|3.0|Pantera's 7th album is perhaps the most aggressively personal offering of their entire career but unfortunately this has its upsides and downsides.    The album kicks off with Strength Beyond Strength, it immediately establishes the tone of the album offering nothing but a heavy groove and brutal drumming throughout. Unfortunately the groove does not sustain itself for very long and soon it begins to show that was a wonderful intro does not turn into a wonderful song. Dimebag's guitar-work and Vinnie Paul's drumming are its only saving grace. The lyrics are nonsensical and Anselmo seems to be trying far too hard to find any real rage in this subject.    Becoming is the album's second track and here things turn completely in the other direction. Anselmo draws from personal experiences and delivers a truly menacing diatribe on self-image/self-worth set to a fantastically catchy and creative groove. Next up is another brutal offering and another staple in Pantera's catalog: 5 Minutes Alone. Supposedly inspired by an encounter with a fan's enraged father, here Anselmo turns the tables and places himself in the role of said character. Once again painting a picture of finding one-self in a hostile environment it is easy to see why the song appeals to fans of the band. The riffs are absolutely brutal, with no apologies or breaks and Anselmo growl hits a high mark towards the end of the song as his bestial growling of the chorus echo and slowly fade away.    What follows is one of the more self-indulgent offerings in Pantera's catalog. Good Friends and a Bottle of Booze must have seemed like a good, short \\"song\\" to give listeners a break from the aggressive barrage that the album has been building up to this point. However, because of the lyrical content the song comes across as some sort of in-joke between Anselmo and whoever he is directing these words at, if anyone. Boasting is all to be found here and Vinnie Paul's catchy drumming is the track's only redeeming quality.Hard Lines, Sunken Cheeks provides the appropriate cease-fire in Pantera's aural assault. A slow (for Pantera), grinding intro is followed by a fast tempo and Anselmo quickly spewing forth on his decadent life. The chorus periodically slows things down and returns to the grind that served as the intro. A very melodic solo is a note-worthy highlight of this track as well. Slaughtered's machine gun riffs follow with somewhat forgettable lyrics and vocals but a tremendous groove throughout.     25 Years continues to provide some insight into Phil Anselmo's past by revealing his feelings towards a certain paternal figure in a very graphic way. The song itself is hardly worth including as an album track though. Overly simplistic and reminiscent of Good Friends and A Bottle of Booze, it feels like a badly written diatribe with a theme far too common to be of any interest if Anselmo weren't such an enigmatic figure. As it is the aforementioned is the only reason why this track is even slightly note-worthy.    Shedding Skin follows 25 Years in seemingly giving a glimpse into Anselmo's relationships. This time the lyrics apparently deal with friendships or romantic relationships and trust therein. A fantastic chorus is one of the highlights and the groove, slow and steady, eventually builds into a solo that gives way to pounding finale.    Use My Third Arm and Throes of Rejection close the album's original content with disappointing lyrics but powerful, if somewhat forgettable, melodies. The former touches on the anarchist mindset while the latter deals with the insecurities of dating. Both topics get a far too familiar and simplistic treatment with the lyrics sometimes bordering on throwaway lines. Musically the highlight of the two is Throes of Rejection, which sets off with pounding drums and menacing riffs, as if announcing an incoming showdown. Sadly what is delivered thereafter remains very catchy musically but poorly conceived lyrically.    The closer on the albumis a cover of Black Sabbath's Planet Caravan. As far as covers go it is a very faithfully adaptation of the original, perhaps a little too faithful for its own good. To their credit Pantera more than do justice to this classic but the song simply does not fit in with the rest of the mood the album has been building up to this point.    Far Beyond Driven shows its true colors from the very beginning by setting off on an aggressive binge that seldom lets up. At times Pantera seems to be trying far too hard to enhance the unfiltered rage that was captured in Vulgar Display of Power and this leads to some disappointing tracks. Nonetheless, amongst the failed attempts, lay some true gems from Pantera's catalogue that successfully manage to one-up vulgar Display of Power in its venomous bite.

B000088DSQ|4.0|I was surprised by the universal acclaim on this recording. Whilst there are some moments of real joy and surprise, as a whole the set feels somewhat uneven. The first three concertos are the best of the set, four is OK but five is disappointing. At times liberties are taken with tempi and you find things grinding to a halt abruptly and the performance loses forward momentum as a result, at other times things feel a little too mechanical. <br /> <br />This is particularly apparent in the slow movement of number 5, one of my favourite piece of Beethoven. It is really difficult to tell whether it is intended or a by-product of recording but at times the piano is just too much to the fore and sounds like a mechanical music box. It is somewhat surprising by Aimard seems to be able to combine over use of rubato (the opening phrases in the piano just slow down too much) with overly spiky approaches to passages where the piano accompanies the orchestra. <br /> <br />I have to say though that the orchestra is wonderful throughout under Harnoncourt. <br /> <br />Word of advice - don't listen to this with headphones - you can hear the edits to remove audience noise and also hear someone (wither the conductor or soloist) audibly grunting with the effort in places - quite unnerving.
