0380733358|4.0|Eye of the Needle is the first book Follett wrote that became succussful and established him as a great writer, especially of historical, WWII novels.  Now, after several years and several novels, Eye of the Needle holds up well.  It tells the story of the Allies' deception at D-Day.  The Allies convinced Germany the attack would be at Calais, not at Normandy.  How did they do this?  Follett writes about it in this novel.  Germany's success in spying on the Allies has been mostly a failure, but one spy has mananged to avoid authorities and also found out an incredible truth:  The plan to attack at Calais is one big fabrication.  How will he get the info to Germany.  The Germans won't trust a radio transmission because too many agents have been turned by the British.  This spy, the Needle, has to get photographs to Germany.<br /><br />The Needle is the main character, and we follow him as he travels across the country always one step ahead of the authorities.  The story also follows the British men in MI5 trying to track the Needle.  These men are civillians pressed into duty for their country and do an admirable job.  Another part of the story is that of David and Lucy Rose.  On their wedding night and the day before David is supposed to report for duty, he is involved in a car wreck that takes both of his legs.  He and Lucy move to Storm Island and become recluses from society.  David also withdrawals from Lucy which leaves her desparate for human interaction.  Lucy is a strong character, but she doesn't become a part of the story until the later.<br /><br />This Follett novel is very good and in it you see what made him so successful.  Still, it is not one of his bests, but definitely a must read.
0385720920|4.0|This book was written by Chuck Palahniuk and it is a story about a troubled man named Victor Mancini.  This novel is full of dark witty humor that exemplifies the reluctance to accepting love.  Victor goes to restaurants and pretends to choke on food, attends weekly sex addiction meetings and has an ailing mother in need of a stomach pump.  He is a man but with a deep past, a past that he thinks he has settled.  As a child Victor moved from many different foster homes, he always ran away back to his mother, who was in and out of jail for her actions that showed she was not of mental health.  The beginning of the novel starts off in the middle of the night, at the edge of a forest near the base of a rock cliff.  Victor is standing in the freezing winter snow, completely naked except for jeans; he is standing in front of a bus facing its high beams and he is waiting for his mother to finish spray painting his shadow against the rock cliff.  She tells him to stand up straight or he will ruin her work of art, she says sculpture and pictures were started from a shadow and that one day Victor will understand.  She returns to jail soon after this and Victor is left with pneumonia and a feeling of disgust at his malleable former childhood self.  Victor refers to himself as a stupid little boy because he was so eager to have love, which he thought was what his mother was doing but in reality she was mentally unstable.  Victor endured moments like these and countless others.   <br /> After this particular moment, his life is built around his rejection of love, he views himself as unlovable.  He has sex randomly, often masturbating in public, with numerous people and all the while he goes to restaurants across town and pretends to choke on food.  He describes his first time choking, not purposely and notices that \\"you [have] to risk your life to get love\\" (3).  Chuck Palahniuk shows Victor as someone who is choking on food for money to pay off his debts he owes on account of his ailing mother who is on her death bed.  However, the underlining message is that Victor fails to notice that his life is built around love; he is loving and has a good heart but disregards this aspect of himself through lying and swindling money out of people.  Palahniuk clouds Victor, justifying his actions of choking by stating that everyone wants to be a hero, leaving Victor to play the victim, the helpless boy that cannot survive well enough on his own.  Palahniuk creates two worlds, one in which Victor is just a sex addict who cheats people out of their money and pride however there is a less obvious and more subtle alternate reality that shows Victor as someone plagued by his past, someone struggling to love himself and allow others to love him. <br /> Victor attends sex addiction meetings three times a week however he usually doesn't make it to the inside of the meeting room because he is having sex in the janitors closet with another group member.  Each addict most complete a twelve step program, Victor is stuck on his fourth step.  In order to complete this step Victor must take inventory of his life, write down every moment of addiction he has, not just sex but moments that have stuck with him.  Throughout the whole novel Victor delays on completing this step, here Palahniuk sheds light into Victor's hurtful past.  Victor sees the reasoning behind the fourth step and even states that \\"those who forget [their] past are condemned to repeat it\\" (8).  However his reluctance to complete the step is an issue Palahniuk creates in order to cloud the softer side of Victor; his softer side isn't as obvious as Victor's sexual drive or his willingness to steal from helpful strangers.  Victor lives a life that demands too much of him, forcing him to foolish means.  Palahniuk does an excellent job of creating Victor as the enemy, while reading Choke I noticed myself feeling angry at the stupidity of Victor's actions however my contradicting feelings towards Victor exemplifies Palahniuk's ability to appeal to all levels of his readers emotions.   <br />Chuck Palahniuk allows for a broad range of feelings and does an excellent job of creating two worlds within the character Victor.  These two worlds can go unnoticed to the untrained eye but there is no denying Palahniuk's skill for deeper meaning while assessing his ability to craft witty, dark humored sentences.  Choke and more importantly the character Victor is filled with the usage of double entendre, everything is more than the surface and Palahniuk gives subtle hints to the two lives of Victor Mancini; the person Victor is fighting and the person he would be if he stopped fighting.  Throughout the novel there is only a faint recognition of this however the end of the novel is where things come to surface.  At the end I found myself with one word at the tip of my astonished lips and that was `wow'.  <br />         <br />  <br />       <br />

0307237699|5.0|The first thing Obama accomplishes in _Audacity_ is to stake out his position on the major issues of the day.  For the most part his is a consistent liberal stand- he's for abortion, against the death penalty, against the Bush tax cuts, against the war, he voted against CAFTA, and he's for expanded government health care, a higher minimum wage, and against privatizing social security.<br /><br />All these are classic liberal positions, but as you read his book you will notice that he doesn't advance simplistic liberal arguments for his positions.  He understands how free markets work.  He's for affirmative action, but he argues that racism is not the primary cause of back inequality.  He's the last one you would hear blaming racism for the Hurricane Katrina mishap.  He understands that poverty in Africa is caused by corruption; liberals argue the reverse.  He supports many of the policies of the teachers' unions, but understands that they are part of the problem.  Although he consistently comes down on the side of liberal policies, his reasoning is moderate.  He has yet to find a hot issue that would separate him from the liberal crowd (merit pay is one, but it's not hot) as Clinton did with the death penalty and welfare reform.<br /><br />The author to whom he is most indebted is William Julius Wilson.  Like Wilson, he sees the both racism and cultural failure as a major cause of racial inequality and his policy recommendations (for universal rather than targeted social policies) come very close to what Wilson called the \\"hidden agenda\\" in the _Truly Disadvantaged_.  And his politics and political strategy draws much from Wilson's _The Bridge over the Racial Divide_ with its somewhat nave hopes for transcending partisanship.<br /><br />What clearly separates him from many of the other candidates is that he understands the arguments on the other side of these issues. He describes the arguments for many Bush administration policies far better than even Bush does.  He voted against CAFTA but explains why it was not an easy choice. More than most, he understands that almost every policy decision has its plusses and minuses.  Contrast this with our president and many other politicians, liberal and conservative, who see almost every decision as a choice between right and wrong.<br /><br />In the end, presidents face choices that are far more complex than the simplistic issues that come up in campaigns; if you understand how a candidate thinks (or, in the case of one successful candidate, refuses to think) and deals with those who disagree with him, you will have a much better idea of what kind of president he is going to be.<br /><br />And Obama writes better than Wilson does, and better than he did his first book (which dragged on an unnecessary 40 pages).<br /><br />My grandmother used to say, \\"politicians are like nails -- the go in straight and come out crooked\\".  I hope Barak is the exception.<br /><br />Gary Klass<br />gmklass@ilstu.edue voted against CAFTA but explains why it was not an easy choice. More than most, he understands that almost every policy decision has its plusses and minuses.  Contrast this with our president and many other politicians, liberal and conservative, who see almost every decision as a choice between right and wrong.<br /><br />In the end, presidents face choices that are far more complex than the simplistic issues that come up in campaigns; if you understand how a candidate thinks (or, in the case of one successful candidate, refuses to think) and deals with those who disagree with him, you will have a much better idea of what kind of president he is going to be.<br /><br />And Obama writes better than Wilson does, and better than he did his first book (which dragged on an unnecessary 40 pages).<br /><br />My grandmother used to say, \\"politicians are like nails -- the go in straight and come out crooked\\".  I hope Barak is the exception.<br /><br />Gary Klass<br />gmklass@ilstu.edu

B00005Y1TL|4.0|Many years ago, when I first heard this CD, I thought that it was rather empty, bleak, and just dull cold electronic music.  There wasn't much like it around at the time, so when I played this CD a few times, I got tired of it rather quickly.  I even ended up giving it a way to a friend.<br /><br />Then, a few years later, I saw a movie called \\"Pi\\".  It was a low budget black and white film based on the subject of intelligence and insanity, and the soundtrack that supported this film had a series of artists that I have never heard of before.  Watching the film, I just loved all that strange electronic music playing in the background, so I knew I just had to find the CD soundtrack of the film \\"Pi\\".<br /><br />On the soundtrack, I saw that Aphex Twin had a track on it.  I don't remember this track in the film \\"Bucephalus Bouncing Ball\\", but I sure loved this bizarre electronic collage of dissonant noise.  Plus, this CD soundtrack introduced me to alot of new artists, all making a new sound in electronic music that I have never heard before.  This new music is called IDM, which means \\"intelligent dance music\\".  But, I think it should be called ADM meaning \\"addictive music\\", because that's what this new music has become to me.  I have a hard time listening to regular music anymore.  This IDM is very motivational music to listen to.  This music gives me all sorts of nervous energy which has turned me into a healthier, more physically toned, workaholic.  When I'm in an IDM music euphoria, I can't sit still.  After buying the soundtrack of \\"Pi\\", I ended up buying this Aphex Twin CD once again and listened to it with a more optimistic, more educated awareness, of what is being played here.<br /><br />But, you know, you can't just allow yourself to be satisfied with this one CD.  You have to let yourself explore more music like Aphex Twin.  And I'm not too crazy about all of Aphex Twin's CD's (Selected Ambient Works: Volume Two is actually a very boring double CD to have to listen to, and it's nothing like this Volume One).  However, if you don't have a lot of music like this, than it can seem to become too repetitious and become tiresome rather quickly if you let yourself play this CD too much.  Even I don't care to sit through the entire playback of just the one CD.  But, I have determined that this music from Aphex Twin should be played within a mix of other Ambient Dub and other various glitch and IDM related electronica.  To just play these 13 songs over and over, end to end, can get dull quickly.  But if you listen to these songs mixed in with about another hundred IDM instrumentals than you will truly appreciate Aphex Twin's participation in the overall bigger picture of today's electronic instrumentals. Today's IDM.<br /><br />I have this Aphex Twin CD shuffling amongst others in my 200 CD carrousel.  These tracks by Aphex Twin are being mixed up with tracks by Autechre, Gescom, Squarepusher, Pete Namlook, Biosphere, The Orb, The Higher Intelligence Agency, Phutureprimitive, Sounds From the Ground, Electric Skychurch, Plaid, Boards of Canada, and various other similar artists of which Aphex Twin belongs with.<br /><br />I also have these songs and other IDM and Ambient Dub tracks burned onto ATRAC CDR's that is made through the SonicStage program made available only by Sony.  (Check out some of Sony's ATRAC CD players and find out why burning hours of your favorite tunes onto a single CDR is better than just loading an ipod with mp3s)  Burning hard copies is definitely better than just floating your music in a temporary storage unit like an ipod.  (You can make 32 hour CDR's, and as many as you want from all your CD's and mp3s.  How many songs can your single ipod hold?)<br /><br />Anyway, Kudos to you for discovering this particular Aphex Twin CD, but now, explore some of the other artists I've mentioned above.  You will love this new world of sound that you've discovered.  It is more vast than you could ever imagine.ave to listen to, and it's nothing like this Volume One).  However, if you don't have a lot of music like this, than it can seem to become too repetitious and become tiresome rather quickly if you let yourself play this CD too much. 037571457X|5.0|I loved this book for many of the same reasons other reviewers did. As others mention, there's a lot in this book that's unique:  the freshness and the perfect fit of the comic book style to the content, the heroine's pluck and total believability, and the author's success in portraying both the \\"good and the bad\\" of growing up in post-revolution Iran with amazing lack of preachiness, or heavy-handedness (she lets the story speak, and lets us judge accordingly). True such an accomplishment can be viewed in numerous other first hand accounts of foreign cultures. But Satrapi truly stands out as a genius in this genre. When I am taken on a voyage along with a girl (or boy)into the heart of a \\"different\\" culture by an author as skilled as Satrapi, a series of transformations take place in me, that lead to my acute awareness of that well-kept secret in this world of ours that I too always seem to forget--that what is common among humans (which includes most of what is in our hearts) completely transcends time and place. I see yet again how ephemeral this insight is, and how easy it is to fall prey to the thousand-fold repeated LIE: \\"we are different from others, and we must believe the self-appointed authorities on HOW we are different\\".  This book once again shows me the light--and this time, with the help of Satrapi's story, so lightly yet so compellingly delivered, I have more faith that this truth will stay with me.  And I hope that its magic will do the same for all its readers.

B0000028VT|4.0|The album was first rate..except the bonus track (on the orginal CD)..\\"Everything Fades Away\\" was missing.... This bonus track was a highlight was ordering the product online...else the CD quality,re- mastering..the packaging etc are all superb.. <br />
B0000DZ3HM|5.0|As has been noted by nearly every reviewer of the recently reissued DVD version of \\"One Night With Blue Note\\", the changes to the original film (made in 1985 and released on VHS and laserdisc) are controversial and questionable. No one can say the enhanced image and sound quality aren't improvements, and the additional music is certainly welcome, but this was a movie made by a filmmaker with a very clear intent - to show the intimate interplay between jazz musicians. This was accomplished through extended close-ups and very observant musical intercutting. Director John Jopson and Cinematographer Ernest Dickerson did a masterful job in capturing the personalities of the musicians and it seems a shame to randomly throw in audience shots from some other event - and in video format at that. (I wonder what those people think watching this DVD, seeing themselves enjoying a show they never attended.)<br /><br />To film more than forty of the greatest jazz musicians in the world for over 3 hours is a daunting task. This movie was shot on film, not video, so there had to be film magazine changes every ten minutes on each of the multiple cameras. To do this without missing important moments is incredibly difficult and requires planning, a good ear, and spontaneity. On the original version there was a great interplay during one set where we see Freddie Hubbard's amazed reaction to Herbie Hancock's piano solo. This shot really said something - how these musicians can blow each other away. Throughout the film the Director doesn't hesitate to cut away to what the other musicians are doing, even during a solo. To be fair much of this artful editing is still intact, but it's a disservice to the filmmaker and the viewer to go back in and change the intent.<br /><br />Most importantly, thanks to Bruce Lundvall and Michael Cuscuna the greatest night in jazz history has been well documented, and at least we know the original footage is still in the Blue Note vaults in case some futureaficionado wants to restore the film to its original form for the next generation. Or how about releasing a Director's Cut? I'll bet everyone who owns the DVD would buy yet another version: We know from the CDs and the tracks that were removed from the original version (ie the Charles Lloyd and Stanley Jordan tunes) that there must be a lot of footage yet to be released.<br /><br />Nevertheless the DVD version is still an incredible film and well worth the investment. If you're a jazz lover buy the DVD and look for the vhs or laserdisc on eBay. \\"One Night With Blue Note\\" is simply the best jazz movie ever made.
B000I5Y8ZU|4.0|I'm writing this review for all the ancient relics (i.e. those old enough to drink) who may have read about this new My Chemical Romance album but aren't sure if they should care about it.  Begging your indulgence, I'll also be making numerous references to a lot of past albums.  This is mainly because MCR themselves seem to be self-consciously referencing these albums to fashion \\"The Black Parade.\\"  While I suppose that may signal some of you to assume that no, you really shouldn't care, I'll tell you that you should, with a definite, resounding and emphatic \\"maybe.\\"<br /><br />First off, I'll get those pesky references out of the way.  One of us old folks, a geezer named Billy Corgan, is probably gnashing his teeth at the very thought of \\"The Black Parade,\\" since it clearly and obviously pays a huge debt to his old band the Smashing Pumpkins and their massive and self-consciously important concept album \\"Mellon Collie and the Infinite Sadness\\" (still one of the most ridiculous titles for an album, even after all these years).  Of course, massive and self-consciously important concept albums have a long and venerable history in rock, and \\"The Black Parade\\" manages to remind us of almost every single one of them.  Aside from \\"Mellon Collie,\\" one can easily find bits, pieces and even whole undigested chunks from \\"Sgt. Pepper\\" (of course), Pink Floyd's \\"The Wall\\" (the story of the life of an alienated rocker), Nine Inch Nails' \\"The Downward Spiral\\" (dark lyrics, frequently about suicide and disease) and even Marilyn Manson's \\"Antichrist Superstar\\" (the transformation of a nobody into Somebody Important).  There are also plenty of musical nods to Queen (\\"A Night at the Opera\\") and yes, even Green Day's more recent \\"American Idiot.\\"  I myself was also reminded a bit of Husker Du's indie-punk landmark \\"Zen Arcade\\" (has MCR even heard of that one?).  I could go on, and you can probably add to the list, but us old folks need a breather sometimes, you know?<br /><br />Anyway, what does \\"The Black Parade\\" add to the sub-genre?  In theory, not a whole lot, but in practice, the band's tuneful punk (I refuse to say the word \\"emo\\"--damn!) melds itself pretty well with multi part anthems like \\"Welcome To The Black Parade\\" and \\"Famous Last Words.\\"  While the lyrical content gushes with teen angst and overblown despair (\\"Have you heard the news that you're dead?/No one ever had much nice to say/I think they never liked you anyway\\"), it's played with so much energy that when they get to the inevitable uplift (I am not afraid to keep on living/I am not afraid to walk this world alone\\") it seems almost unnecessary.  I suppose one can complain about their lack of musical diversity--they stick mostly to the old-fashioned guitar/bass/drums lineup, albeit every bit as overproduced as any of the albums mentioned before.  Compare, if you will, with the more lo-fi, but way more musically adventurous \\"In the Aeroplane Over the Sea\\" by Neutral Milk Hotel (zanzithophone, anyone? wandering genie?).  On a couple of tracks, MCR do add a certain Weimar Cabaret feel.  Okay, so have the Dresden Dolls and even Marilyn Manson (\\"The Golden Age of Grotesque\\"), but do those guys have a cameo from Liza Minelli?  She appears for a few brief but insane moments on \\"Mama,\\" even if it goes by so fast you hardly notice it.  Really, the whole album breezes by so fast you hardly notice it, much less stop to ponder all those other albums or what this album has to say, all in all.  I'll leave that one open for interpretation, but I'm sure the masses of immature hormonal youth that idolize the band will fill in that just nicely.  Actually, I kind of feel the need to apologize for liking the album, since the kind of ambition it requires to make such a grand statement inevitably leads to a total sacrifice of street cred.  Still, my fellow hoary crypt-keepers, if you can tear yourselves away from your nostalgia to the bygone days B.D. (before Dubya) for less than an hour, you mayeven want to join in this parade.may even want to join in this parade.

6305949980|5.0|Wow, THE NIGHTMARE BEFORE CRISTMAS has to be one of the greatest animated films ever made. In it, Tim Burton creates a fantastic and brilliantly imagined world full of magic and wonder. The movie captures the viewer's imagination from the beginning and never lets go. Each frame is filled with enchanting imagery, from pumpkin patches to glistening snow fields. The musical numbers are superb, ranging from jazzy show tunes (Oogie Boogie's Song) to hauntingly beautiful ballads (Jack's Lament.) These songs have wonderful melodies, superb vocals and intelligent lyrics that add emotional depth to the film and advance its plot. The amount of detail in this movie is just amazing and rewards repeated viewings. The characters are fascinating and their voices, motions and expressions are all flawlessly done. Danny Elfman really deserves a lot of credit for putting so much emotion into the singing voice of Jack and writing such a great score. The movie goes from darkly funny to moving and everything in between. A wonderful film that delights the senses and imagination.   DON'T MISS IT!

B000FIMG68|5.0|I came to \\"Lost\\" a bit differently than some people in that I watched the entire first season on DVD before I ever saw an episode on television. I saw the last few episodes of season two on television and then got all caught up when the second season came out on DVD. This is actually a great way to watch \\"Lost\\" as you don't have the frustraton of waiting a week between episodes.<br /><br />I haven't decided if I think season two is stronger or weaker than season one. I just look at it as part of a continuing journey. I am not as concerned with the island mysteries as I am with the characters. To me, it is all about how these people react and cope with whatever is before them. The acting and writing remain fantastic. And I love the way the show does the unexpected, such as focusing on Desmond, a character not seen since the first episodes of the season and probably forgotten about by most people, for the season finale. And it was a great finale.<br /><br />I hope the show maintains its high level in season 3, and as long as the writers stay true to the characters, I'll be watching.
